summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan, opposing Ghislaine Maxwell's defense requests. The government argues against disclosing witness names 11 months before trial and against court intervention in her Bureau of Prisons confinement conditions. It details the status of discovery production and addresses Maxwell's complaints about her detention.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330). The government is opposing her defense team's requests for early witness disclosure and intervention in her jail conditions.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The government's letter is addressed to her, opposing the defense's motions.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The signatory of the government's opposition letter, submitting it on behalf of the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.

connections.description: Maxwell is the defendant in the criminal case over which Judge Nathan is presiding. The government is submitting a letter to Judge Nathan opposing motions filed by Maxwell's defense.

events.title: Defense Letter Filed
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team files a letter requesting the court order the government to disclose witness names and intervene in her Bureau of Prisons confinement conditions.

events.title: Protective Order Docketed
events.description: The protective order for the case is posted to the docket, following the court's signing on July 30, 2020. The government attributes timing delays to the defense's initial refusal to agree to terms.

events.title: Initial Discovery Production
events.description: The government produces an initial discovery batch totaling more than 12,000 pages to the defense.

events.title: Second Discovery Production
events.description: The government makes a second discovery production, totaling more than 150,000 pages, principally consisting of financial records.

events.title: Maxwell Receives First Discovery
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell receives her copy of the government's first discovery production at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC).

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The government had produced over 165,000 pages of discovery to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense in less than two weeks following the entry of a protective order.
The government opposes disclosing the names of victims/witnesses 11 months before trial, citing legal precedent and a desire to protect victim privacy.

The Bureau of Prisons (BOP) is housing Maxwell separately from the general population for safety and security reasons but plans to provide extended daily access (7 a.m. to 8 p.m.) for her to review discovery.
The government notes the defense had not yet asked a single substantive question about the discovery produced.
The document references a sealed protective order and implies defense counsel in related civil matters may have referenced receiving sealed materials from the criminal case.
